- It seems to me that this op can be separated into two ops, sum op and elementwise product op.

Thanks for being patient on this and great contribution. Can you please do a lint on your file? like

``` bash
dmlc-core/script/lint.py cpp mxnet cpp example/cpp
```

You can add this path to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L145 so it is automatically checked by travis This should detect most of common things linter complained on, I commented a few. This is just to make sure the project have consistent programming style :)

After this is done, please 
- Rename the suffix from .cpp to .cc
- update the PR to add yourself to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md
- Squash the commits to meaningful ones via http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-combine-multiple-commits-into-one 
  - So each commit means meaningful progress.

Then it is good to be merged.

@hjk41 
Cool.
Will working remotely be OK?

I am working on C++ interface too, and It is part of my current work.

**I am far from finishing reading the code now, so correct me if I was wrong.**

I think it it not like dynamic languages, such as Python, R and Java, new operators registered cannot be seen by C++ during runtime, so one has to expose them by hand.
And during this, something awkward happens.

To use the symbol and graph, which I think is quite useful, one has to make the operator a symbol first.
This includes setting up the parameters, and as far as I know, two ways to do so:

Check the code here:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/convolution-inl.h#L364
and here:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/include/mxnet/c_api.h#L402

Either way includes something like this:
**You transfer a integer to string, Mxnet transfers string back to integer.**

And notice that the parameters in operators are always private, so you cannot change it by hand(not mention that the parameters are not exposed to users at all). You must use the ways described previously.

So I don't know any better ways to avoid this, and my suggestion:
Why not just expose part of each operators( especially the parameters) to (c/cpp) users as a header, and this not seem to increase the amount of work when adding new operators.

hi guys, many thanks for the comments. the doc is updated and now available at https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/overview_zh.md
@mli This sounds like a good solution

Totally possible. Was fooling around with it myself. I was able to push it up to 100 residual layers for fun and things still seemed to work. The code bellow isn't _exactly_ what was in the paper and is probably terrible application of the idea but it should give you an idea on how to implement it.

``` python
def ConvFactory(data, num_filter, kernel, stride=(1,1), pad=(0, 0), act_type="relu"):
    conv = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=kernel, stride=stride, pad=pad)
    bn = mx.symbol.BatchNorm(data=conv)
    act = mx.symbol.Activation(data = bn, act_type=act_type)
    return act

def ResidualFactory(data):
    l1 = ConvFactory(data, 32, kernel=(3,3), pad=(1,1))
    l2 = ConvFactory(l1, 32, kernel=(3,3), pad=(1,1))
    return l2 + data


def get_symbol(num_classes = 10):
    data = mx.symbol.Variable(name="data")
    o = ConvFactory(data=data, kernel=(3,3), pad=(1,1), num_filter=32, act_type="relu")
    for i in range(100):
        o = ResidualFactory(o)
    pool = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=o, pool_type="avg", kernel=(32,32), name="global_pool")

    flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool, name="flatten1")

    fc = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=num_classes, name="fc1")

    label = mx.symbol.Variable("softmax_label")
    softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc, name="softmax", label=label)

```

should be resolved by #932 

@cjnewstar111 you may consider to pass `--kv-store local_allreduce_device` more info https://github.com/mli/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification#note-on-performance

@qiaohaijun i follow the notations from the paper [the slow learners are faster](http://alex.smola.org/papers/2009/LanSmoZin09.pdf), which is also compatible with the notations of  bertsekas at mit (i'm a big fan of him). while i guess the petuum guys use the notations from database, one of the original [paper](http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~jcipar/papers/lazybase-eurosys2012.pdf)   

i changed opinions to several guys at nips, i think ssp (or bounded delay) is not necessary at this moment for two reasons:
1. neither significant improvement on speed nor on convergence, due to the gpu dense operation performance is quite uniform.
2. what really matters is a special kind of straggler, namely one worker is blocked for several minutes, and then comes alive again. we probably want to reject its results based on very ancient weights
LGTM. I think this should fix it
@tqchen could you take a look at this?

Nice catch, need to add delete r; after 

```
MSHADOW_CATCH_ERROR(r->Release());
```

This need to be done in lambda function so that it is delayed executed.
Can you open a PR to solve this?
related #891
seems CUDNN_MAJOR is a good way to do so, let us stick with that
This is a great idea

Sorry for the delay! Just get back from NIPS. I like the idea of executor manager as it wraps data parallel pattern  we need. 

The UpdateManager, however, seems was a thin wrapping of the steps that was in the  `_train_multi_device`. I would suggest we remove this by either putting things back, or replace them by two functions in `model.py`.

Some comments
- The general principle of adding modules(another layer of abstraction) is to make pieces re-usable among multiple places, in this case, there is not an example where the two things are used.
- Function is usually preferred over classes when there are few ops as normally this makes less cause side-effect between calls
also loop in @pluskid @antinucleon @mli
It's probably better to make Updater a method in KVStore. Since it's only needed if kvstore is used. otherwise a simple update call will be enough
The best way to keep things up to date with pulls, is simply remove all installations from user side, and add the mxnet/python to PYTHONPATH

I like the idea of crashing the giant `_train_multi_device` method into pieces. This looks good to me, though I do think using methods instead of extra classes is preferred. For example, `ExecutorManager` sounds like a very general thing, but actually here it only does data parallelization.
All the model parameters are in the argument arrays, so should be straight-forward. Unfortunately since BN is a cross image operator so it is impossible to get gradient when you change batch size
for speed reasons, normally you only need to implement the Operator using C++ and compose them with python
moving discussion directly to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet.js/issues/2
@tqchen do you know how to modify the makefile for that?

Thanks a lot for the suggestion. 

Basically, I did not need to build a whole new layer. Since the nice design of symbolic and binding executors, I just need to implement the outer gradient for the executor to do backward. The whole model also used the dmlc/experiment-lda, which is a fast sampler. The whole project would be better in cpp for speed. 

By the way, another question is sparse input feature for neural nets. I use the neural nets for modeling text and using side information as feature input. Therefore, the input is very sparse. I use NDArray as input, so it would be a very sparse matrix from the view of numpy array. Is this okay and efficient to use NDArrary? Or it has some better way to do so?
There is a special operator called embedding that takes sequence of text. We will indeed need a sparse matrix dot product operator

Yes sometimes the feature input size could be very large but also very sparse for modeling text. Not only the spare matrix dot product operator, but also the NDArray(maybe a special SparseNDArray)? 

I just configured the symbols and bind it with the NDArray as feature input. Storing in such sparse data, (like index map, if the index existed, then get 1 for the index) with numpy matrix could be also be waste of memory.

Hi, @tqchen , thanks for your comment. But I think maybe it's a no downsample network. I mean, input an image and get an image out. Look at the figure 1 and 2. How can I write such example in mxnet?

@JamesKnowton You will have to use `SoftmaxOutput` with `multi_output=true` to get a multidimensional feature map with probabilities. For multi-task learning you can use several independent `SoftmaxOutput` layers.
I don't think mxnet currently has maxout, so you will have to implement that as an activation function.

It works when I use LinearRegressionOutput

``` python
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np

trX = np.linspace(-1, 1, 101)
trY = 2 * trX + np.random.randn(*trX.shape) * 0.33

X = mx.sym.Variable('data')
Y = mx.sym.Variable('softmax_label')

Y_ = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=X, num_hidden=1)

cost = mx.sym.LinearRegressionOutput(data=Y_, label=Y)

model = mx.model.FeedForward(symbol=cost, num_epoch=100, learning_rate=0.05, numpy_batch_size=1)

model.fit(X=trX, y=trY)
```
1. How can I define my own loss?
2. How can I access the weights of the FeedForward network?

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15868412/11801100/83f85e78-a31d-11e5-8a62-4582f009e75f.png)

I get your point, the major problem was to get a good sugar with support for reflection style interface. It is interesting to ask how to create a language sugar for composing symbols. Maybe something from @mavenlin 's purine could be borrowed.

For example, 

``` c++
Net << Op("FullyConnected") << set("num_hidden", 10) << set("no_bias", true)
       << Op("Activation") << set("act_type", "relu");
```

Please open a new issue (say. C++ syntax sugar for symbolic consturction) to discussion this question.
